nodes.text: Major infrastructure projects systematically underestimate costs and overestimate benefits, causing inefficient project selection and chronic project failures

Characteristics of major infrastructure projects: long horizons, complex interfaces, nonstandard technology, multi-actor decision making, lock-in of concepts, scope changes, and inadequate contingencies

Dataset and empirical method: large-sample databases of transportation projects (cost data: 258 projects; demand data: 208 projects) using constant-price comparisons of estimated versus actual outcomes
Result: High and persistent cost overruns — rail average 44.7%, bridges and tunnels 33.8%, roads 20.4%; 9 out of 10 projects have cost overruns; overruns stable over 70 years

Result: Large and biased demand forecast errors — rail passenger traffic on average 51.4% lower than forecast (overestimate ~105.6%), road traffic errors smaller and less biased; inaccuracies persistent over 30 years
Claim: Conventional ex ante cost-benefit analysis is unreliable for major infrastructure because inputs (cost and demand forecasts) are systematically biased

Evidence: Case studies where biased forecasts produced non-viable projects (Channel Tunnel: 80% construction overrun, 140% financing overrun, revenues ~50% of forecast; Great Belt tunnel: 120% construction overrun)
Explanations evaluated: technical errors rejected by data, psychological optimism bias insufficient as sole cause, political-economic strategic misrepresentation best fits empirical patterns
Evidence rejecting technical explanation: forecasting errors show systematic bias (means statistically different from zero) and no improvement over decades despite methodological investment

Evidence supporting political-economic explanation: interviews and studies show promoters deliberately understate costs and overstate benefits to win funding, creating incentives for 'showing the project at its best'
Claim: 'Survival of the un-fittest' mechanism — projects that look best on biased paper (largest underestimates/overestimates) are those that perform worst in reality

Method recommendation: Use reference class forecasting (outside view) — identify comparable project class, derive empirical distribution, and adjust specific project forecasts toward reference outcomes

Result: Practical application of reference class forecasting improved realism (example: Edinburgh Tram cost uplift from 320m to 400m to allow 80% contingency; adopted in multiple countries and projects like Crossrail)

Governance reforms proposed: increase transparency and public control (block grants, independent review, public disclosure, hearings), enforce market accountability (private finance without sovereign guarantees, shared financial responsibility), and professional/legal penalties for deception

Conclusion: To reduce waste and avoid 'survival of the un-fittest' combine reference class forecasting with stronger governance and accountability; otherwise stimulus spending, growth in emerging-economy projects, and ICT integration will amplify financial and economic disasters
